Dude, I just told you my order like 3 seconds ago. Plus, you pay for the burrito, all you get is the burrito. Chips and salsa are extra. Extra! That's just straight up nickel and diming you. At least there's a soda fountain so you get refills on your soda. 

In this area, you could probably do worse for a burrito.
author: Saunders C.

description:
I absolutely love Gordo's. I always go to the one on Geary but this one is closest to work.
I got a regular burrito with everything on it except for hot sauce. It was soo good and the worst part is I couldn't eat it at work because it was so busy, it was staring me in the face like EAT ME. 
It's a great place to get a quick burrito and they're probably not as a good as the food in the Mission but if you're in the area you should try it. :)
author: Lana K.

description: This place has ok Mexican food. However, the service is horrible, and is one of the worst around. It reminds me of the soup nazi from Seinfeld... Very unfriendly staff. Will not come here again.
author: Scott S.

description: Decent burritos after a day at the Academy of  Sciences.  Close to Golden Gate Park and great food at a reasonable price.
author: Douglas L.

description:
I zipped in here to grab some food to bring back to the park.
The place is clean, bright, and the prices are very reasonable.
The food, well, eh.

Carnitas were the best part of the meal.
Chicken burritos were just OK.  Chicken quesadilla was oddly greasy - perhaps the grade of cheese that they use?
Even with the requested "spicy" on my burrito, it was not truly spicy.

If I had just moved here, I would think this place is the bomb.  But, now that I have become strong in the ways of the burrito, I know there's much better out there.
author: dan s.

description:
My go to burrito spot in the city. Their carnitas is great, and they use fresh ingredients, and not to mention their portions and prices are both very generous. 

Never had a bad meal here. If I am feeling extra hungry I will go for the all meat super burrito which is sure to sate even my ginormous appetite. 

Their salsa is very good and would recommend that you have them liberally drench the innards of your burrito with both the green and red sauce. 

I would recommend this joint to all burrito lovers.
author: Matt K.

description:
Just fucking yummy. I know that people poo poo this place, but really it's kinda awesome. Huge burritos that always make me feel pleasantly fat afterwards. 

In the grand hierarchy of bay area burritos, the burrito pyramid if you will, Gordo's is perched perilously close to the top.
author: Peter F.

description: Ok so I've been going to gordo for almost 14 years now. It is my go to spot for Mexican food. I am deeply upset with the service I just recieved. I rushed down there to make it before 10pm so I could get some food. When I arrived at 9:50, I was told they were closed. I asked why since it wasn't 10 yet. The answer was they were short staffed. I asked if I could just grab something they had left. This guy with a bunch of piercings and tattoos said "dude we are CLOSED" in a a rude fashion so I began walking out when I heard him mumbling something. When I got to the door, I then heard him say "ok, don't listen to me dude!."I have never been talked to like that by anyone there. This guy needs to go! He is extremely rude and no respect for customers. Very disappointed.
author: andrew c.

description:
"Yo quiero Taco Gordo. Tal vez."

Nice, clean taqueria, a block from GGP. Good place to take super-hungry kids after a long day of activities. Standard fare, okay prices. Tacos and quesadillas are drippy, but flavorful. Burrito was a little dry with all the rice. (In fairness, rice was double-ordered since husband is banned from beans. ;) Can get really busy right at 6pm. Bathroom was clean.

We'd come back if we're in the area again because we know it's there. Although with so many other places to try in The Sunset, it might not be for a long time.
author: Glady L.

description: I loved this place when it first opened, it was smaller and if you dropped in for feeding at least once a week, the guys recognized you.  Then they rennovated and it became just another faceless taqueria.  What really finally turned me off to this place is when I went in and was standing in line and one of the guys making burritos obviously had a cold, was sniffing and wiping his nose with his gloved hand and onto his arms, sneezing, and was making burritos through it all.  Just wasn't very appetizing and, seriously, I do not want to get sick.  I mean, if he absolutely had to work when he was so obviously ill, he should at least have worn a face mask thingy.  They don't offer any salads.
author: Kai T.

description:
Ew. I prefer Taco Bell over this crap any day. And I am in no way a fan of Taco Bell(or the inevitable tummy ache you get after eating it). Mexican food is easily in my top 3 favorite foods, and I will usually settle just to get my fix, but I just cant bring myself to come back to this place. 

Weirdest thing is, the gf loves it! 2 stars for making her happy.
author: Nelson S.

description: Good burritos.  I really good place for a quick bite.  Solid food and really quick service.
author: Annabelle K.

description:
Be aware that I am writing this review without having eaten here.  Why am I reviewing it then, you ask?  Very simple:  I intended to eat here.  I drove over here, went inside, and read the menu.  Then I looked around.  The place was filthy.  I asked the guy behind the counter a few questions about what I was intending to order.  He spoke English just fine, but still didn't seem to have any clue as to what I was asking.  He just sort of shrugged and gave me a "Dunno..."  

Given the overall impression of lack of cleanliness or hygiene, I decided that this might be my opportunity to avoid a potentially gut-wrenching (literally) experience.  

I opted instead to go around the corner onto Irving and eat at La Fonda, which felt clean, well-staffed, and overall a better choice.

So, if you've eaten here a lot and never wound up with a tummy ache, I say jolly good for you!  As for me, though, my stomach and intestines just weren't willing to take the risk.
author: Amy L.

description: The overall quality of the burritos is very average (3/5). However, the poor quality of service (employees seem to be in an inexplainable rush to give you your burrito without putting in all of the ingredients for which you asked) and the lack of sanitary practices (no gloves worn when dealing with ingredients) warrant a sub-average rating.
author: Harneet R.

description:
Last night (August 31)  around 645 pm my friends and I ordered 3 burritos and 2 tacos. The person who prepared our food was great and I was determined to leave a good tip in the jar. However, the cashier spoiled it for everyone. This male cashier (name not known) had tatoos on both his arms. This is the only way to describe him. (BTW, I love tatoos). This cashier was rude to us and had an attitude because the line was long and he seemed hurried. We told him which burritos had guacamole and sour cream because he did not know but he just was plain nasty to our party. Why should I leave a tip in the jar when he was mean but everyone else was pleasant? He ruined it for the other 3 workers.
Customer service was good exept for him. I wish I knew the owner or how to get in contact with ownership to explain what happened. BTW, the food was very good, however, I will not be returning until a different cashier works there. There are other taquerias nearby which are just as good we will go too.

Thank you.
author: D. W.

description:
I come to Gordo's and all of their other Gordo restaurants for one thing and one thing only...their flour quesadilla!!  I swear it is one of thee best I have ever tried and will keep coming back and get my next of kins to come back for this item ONLY!  They fry it a bit on the grill with excess oil that makes the flour tortilla nice and crispy...so crispy it gets flakey with cheese melted right in there.  Their burritos??...their tacos??...blaaaah...nothing to rave about...way many better places in the Mission for those items.

What to order??  Flour quesadilla w/ carne asada...salsa, guacamole, sour cream and hot sauce...THEE BEST...try it...MUST TRY!!
author: Patrick C.

description:
After exploring the deYoung museum and Conservatory of Flowers on a free Tuesday in GGP, my stomach was grumbling. For a quick fix i entered this place. 
Ordered a regular burrito with chicken, pinto bean, rice, salsa, with added sour cream n guacamole. It was $5, pretty cheap! The portion was good. As i was so hungry i immediately dug into the entire burrito. Ended up overeating, but was completely satisfied. No frills, excellent value, fast service.
author: Payal B.

description:
The one thing I like about Gordo's is that they when you place your order you can see exactly what their putting and how much they're putting in your burrito (Pretty much like they do it at Chipotle, BUT I hate Chipotle!).  As opposed to the taquerias where the cashier takes your order and the burrito maker is in the back assembling your gut bomb and you can't see what they're putting inside.  And you're sitting down waiting for your order and they fock it up.  

Definitely recommend the Super Carnitas Burrito.  Carnitas is not dry and the guacamole is chunky, which is the way I like it.  Best taqueria in the Inner Sunset IMHO.  I'd give them 5 stars if they didn't charge extra separately for sour cream and guacamole and I wish they opened later.
author: David C.

description:
Just when I thought I was out... they pull me back in. 

Godfather III was a bad movie. You may watch it and try to convince yourself that it can't be all that bad because there are familiar elements from the beloved earlier burritos... I mean Godfather movies. But, when you view it objectively, there's no denying that it's not even CLOSE to the quality of those other burritos... I mean Godfather movies.

For some reason, I keep going to Gordo in the Inner Sunset even though it's not very good. The thing is, I freaking *love* Godfather movies... I mean burritos. And, I guess even a bad one is better than nothing.

So, just when I thought I was out... they pull me back in. 

I'll be back, Gordo.
author: Horace A.

description:
YAWN! I ate a burrito yesterday from here for the first time, and it was so forgettable, that I had already forgotten the meal halfway through.

Not a BAD choice if you are craving a Chipolte-esque, bland burrito. I have not tried the tacos, so I cannot speak on those, but something tells me I wouldn't be impressed by those either.

I am a native Los Angelan (?) so I'm going with my gut and sticking to eating Mexican food off the truck, as Mexican food was intended to be eaten.
author: Sara D.

description: I live down the street and went in there today to get a couple quick burritos: the worst experience. I walked in with a smile on my face and greeted the dudes working. It took me a couple seconds to know what I wanted to order. When I ordered the man making my burritos was kind and patient. I got the registered where I was ignored for a couple minutes. I was finally acknowledged, for lack of a better word, after the male cashier (sleeve of tattoos) finished his conversation with another coworker from across the room. The entire conversation proceeded with absolutely no eye contact. He immediately gave me the total. I proceeded to ask for chips, Guac, and salsa. He mumbled asking what size. As I politely said regular size, it was easily noticed that he lost patience, breathed in heavily and mumbled, small or large (no eye contact). I felt I was annoying the dude and very under appreciated even though I was at a small burrito shop. I was appalled by the way I was acknowledged and could not bring myself to give my business to these people. Absolutely no respect for me as a person let alone a costumer. I walked out and went to Jenny's. Will not be going back to Gordo due to the lack of costumer service.
author: Maddie R.

description:
No frills, good quality meats in a bigger than average burrito.  Excellent value.  Try the all meat  carne asada burrito w/ guacamole for appetite quencher! 

The perfect place to go to when you're hungry, low on funds, and want something satisfying.
author: MTBer I.

description: I've gone to Gordo's my whole life. My favorite burrito. Perfect to take to the park or before/after visiting the legion of honor
author: Amelia H.

description: Best marinated steak in a quesadilla you will find.  9th street location is the friendliest and well worth finding parking.  I like to grab food and walk out to the park.
author: Ben G.

description:
I have to tell you there are 2 spots I go to mainly between 9th ave and haight street. The first place being Gordo ,the second being Zona Rosa(delicious spot but Im no longer a fan,I may review it)

Anyways, The burittos and the chicken plates are simply the best. A lil sloppy at times, but excellent. I get the half grilled chicken/half steak. D F'n Licious. The atmosphere is pretty laid back, and the staff is friendly. Pricing is affordable , I think they charged me for the chips however,lol.... I suggest anyone looking for good Taqueria in the area give them a shot. I would give them 5 stars but want to reserve that for outta this world reviews...... Cheers
author: scotty t.

description:
We used to live on 14th Ave (@Irving), and regularly ate at Gordo for our burrito fix. I hadn't heard of this place until we moved to the Sunset and hubby introduced me to it. I'm a sucker for a good burrito, and Gordo damn well makes it for me. 

Service is pretty fast, and since we lived there at the time, we had no issues with parking. We may have taken our car there once and circled for parking to grab dinner on our way home from being out, so we know how horrible and frustrating that is. These days, we only visit our old neighborhood, and when we do, we still drop by Gordo. What really is there to say about a good burrito? It's priced just right and it's in a great location.
author: Anio D.

description:
I have gone to this place twice in an attempt to find out why
This place has such a good reputation.  I don't know why. Their
Super burrito isn't bad, but it isn't anything great.  The prices are decent.

Oh, it is easy to get to and the food is ready quick.  But I will probably
Keep going to my local place as they are better, if more expensive.
author: Shawn B.

description: The price is cheap and the portions are decent. The attitude of not all but several  staff keeps me from returning regularly. Standing in line you get to watch nice middle aged people just trying to order dinner be forced to battle through their order from smirking full team jersey wearing servers. I realize food service is a tough business but if you can't at least work without rolling your eyes at every customer then maybe it's not for you. The cashier however is very polite so it's not everyone that works there.
author: Kentaro F.

description:
Yesterday I went to Gordo for the 2nd time, and I have had their regular chicken burrito both times. Really delicious even without the fatty stuff like sour cream, cheese and guacamole. Their standard burrito is filled with Mexican rice, seasoned chicken and a choice of beans. I preferred the refried beans over the cooked pinto beans.

It is also conveniently located across the street from Golden Gate Park which makes it a nice lunch spot if you are visiting the park. Price is also cheap.
author: Richard W.

description: Definitely solid burritos. Not too greasy. No lettuce or anything funky either - a little on the dry side but I'm a fan of that.
author: Michael L.

description: Best burritos in the city!  I love this place.  I'm from the South Bay and I'm used to going to La Victoria.  When I moved to the city, I was afraid I would have trouble finding a suitable replacement.  Now that I've been going to Gordo for the past several years, I don't even remember why I liked La Victoria so much.  Very tasty and juicy burritos.  The customer service is great too.  They keep the line moving so you don't have to wait long.
author: Nicholas G.

description:
Burrito review....There's probably well over 250 taqueria's in the city, but there are a few that have stood out...Gordo's is definitely the college burrito joint and for the inner sunset, this is about as authentic and good tasting as it gets in this hood.  (You just can't beat the mission...) For me, it's the slight bbq char flavor on the grilled chicken/steak along with the soft tortilla.  The rice is meh, but the salsa makes up for it...if there's no line, you can be out of there in 60 seconds for a to go order.

Vamanos!!
author: Darren B.

description: I'm from Los Angeles and Mexican food is what we live on. The food is amazing. The price for the food you get is at equilibrium and the customer service is authentic. It's a pretty dope joint that ill be frequenting.
author: Christopher M.

description:
Gordo's ain't Tlaloc but it's just enough.  For me, a regular chicken burrito with everything except beans...HOLD THE BEANS, POR FAVOR!  I like chopped lettuce in my burritos too but...then again....it ain't a taco...so...yeah, ok...  I always get an extra, small container of their salsa...spicy and added flavor for my somewhat dry burrito... :)

The last time I went, the guy at the counter was making my BF's super burrito...

Me: Ok...just rice...and chicken....
Guy: (points to the beans)
Me: No..NO BEANS
Guy: (points to the guacamole and sour cream)
Me: No, just rice and chicken
Guy: Rice and chicken...that's it?
Me:...........yes.......

Yeah, just rice and chicken is boring but...they dont have lettuce?!  and def dont wants beans...  ok so, his co-worker comes over while the guy is making mine next.  He throws beans on the next one....

Me: Oh!!  No beans, please...
Guy: (pauses...then says something to his co-worker in Spanish...)
Me: (thinking...4 years of Spanish...and I still can't understand what they said...)
Guy: This is for him...
Me: ........oh...ok....HEYYY...did you cut in line?  *chuckle chuckle..*
Guy: (silence...)
Me: (silence...........)

Yeah, they're service is pretty fast and the guy at the cash register is always very nice...but I wish they laughed more often.
author: Kat C.

description:
Simple but oh so delicious. Quick service and made right in front of you as you order.

Chicken burrito: delicious. Say yes to the hot sauce! The chicken is super tasty and tender in a hot flour tortilla. Guacamole and sour cream is an additional cost. The burrito is already satisfying. 

Affordable, quick, and convenient. Good, legit stuff. ;)
author: Stacy G.

description: I discovered Gordo's one day back in my high school days.  My friend told me to get the flour quesadilla with carnitas, rice and the works...my first bite was like heaven...I am now addicted.  It's been almost 20 years and I no longer live in SF BUT each time I fly home for a visit, I ALWAYS make a stop at Gordo's for my carnitas quesadilla...
author: Lei T.

description:
The one thing that I really like about Gordo is their carnitas, some of the best I've tasted. 

The thing that really kills Gordo is the fact that their menu selections are pretty sparse and that they don't steam/heat up their tortillas. This means that the cheese never melts and all the other things that go into their burritos get cold after only a few minutes. Personally I like my burritos warm, my cheese melty. Also their hot sauce has a few things left to be desired too. i've noticed that the guys putting the food together for you don't really take a lot of pride or care into their work. 

Pancho Villa's or Taqueria La Cumbre can teach these guys a few things.
author: Leo V.

description:
This place has some pretty good choices and a juicier burrito than most. They use slices of cheese and melt it onto the tortilla, which is the only difference I can think of when comparing to other taquerias. The rice is not clumpy and the meat is well cooked. Quick service and they don't give you anything to complain about in terms of their service. 

Recently, the one thing that put them over the top is their super quesadilla item. It's a regular quesdilla shell, with cheese and a soft tortilla shortly grilled, but you can put whatever ingredients you want on them. I basically got a standard burrito filling but the slightly crispy wrap was unique and I really enjoyed it. However, besides that, it's difficult to find something that stands out. There's little wrong with it, but besides the super quesadilla, I'd continue exploring the city's many Mexican options, before coming back.
author: Larry Y.

description:
If you are from Boston, this is the Anna's Taqueria of SF.

They move a little more slowly, but the results are good.  Cheap and tasty.

Missing a star as they don't have hot sauce on the tables to use at your discretion.

If I have to drive to a place, I'm going to La Taqueria, but this is a great option if you are around one.
author: Jeff S.

description: We go here often enough to know the workers and duck my head in shame each time I walk in. We have gotten mostly burritos, but their quesadillas are amazing as well. Best price, quick and the product is fresh (and healthy, right?!)
author: Michelle S.

description:
I really, really, REALLY want to like this place.  They're right next to my gym and I pass them every day and I LOVE burritos,  In fact, I've given it 3 tries, w/considerable time in between, ordering different things each time, and each time I was completely disappointed.  Their burritos are the driest I've ever tasted, and I don't even know how that's possible--meat and beans are normally fairly juicy on their own, but they've managed to dessicate both.
The ONLY reason I gave them 2 stars is that they're totally cheap AND they don't automatically assume you want chips, and give you the option to buy those separately, which I appreciate because I don't eat chips.
author: D C.

description:
A few years ago my roommate told me to try this place, claiming that it was one of the best. I denied, but after some persuasion I tried it. And yes he was right, one point for roommate zero for me.

I ordered a regular bean and cheese burrito, yet it was no regular bean and cheese; that thing was massive. It was chock full of beans, rice, cheese and salsa. I tried finishing it in one sitting but half way through it I had to stand up and do some stretches before I continued (okay, maybe that's an exaggeration). I have to admit, it's not the best burrito but it is pretty authentic. If you're looking for a massive traditional style burrito then I recommend Gordos. Just remember to wear your fat pants, cause your belly will stretch!
author: Brent R.

description: Really nothing special. It has a great reputation (many years of ppl saying it's great) but I found the burrito and the salsa especially to lack flavor and an authentic taste. Their chips and salsa was made with all unripe tomatoes and they didn't even bother to add seasoning. I don't get it!
author: kirstenbb c.

description: I love this bay area chain restaurant. It's a nice thing to have if you want to rely on a place to have consistently good and fast Mexican food. I come to Gordo's for burritos and I have yet to be disappointed. Their prices are very affordable and all burritos are large and tasty - as burritos should be!
author: Junel S.

description: The best grilled chicken at a taqueria and they have spinach tortillas! So few places have that option. All the ingredients are good and fresh. I highly recommend this place if you are looking for a good burrito in San Francisco. Don't hesitate based on other reviews, JUST GO.
author: Julie T.

description: Been going here off and on for about 10 years.  Food is usually 3 or 4 star.  This time the carnitas was very dry and almost inedible.  Not sure why given their prices are moderate I would expect better quality.  I'll probably give them one more shot and then abandon them if the food is bad again.
author: Mark L.

description: Its nice that they add Mexican food to the grease that they serve. Very oily for quite mediocre food. There was oil dripping through two brown bags. I am a fan of oil and grease and coronary artery disease, dont get me wrong, but this did not taste good.
author: A I.

description: If you've read the other reviews you probably already know their burritos are on the bland side, but for a moderately priced, decent sized burrito,  this starving college student found an offer she couldn't pass up. They have salt for a reason ladies and gentlemen, so use it. Wasn't the best burrito Ive ever had, but that'll do donkey, that'll do.
author: Brenda L.

description:
When you aren't on the Mission, this is where you go for some really good Mexican food, especially their burritos! I enjoy grabbing food to go and then going across the street to the park because they can be packed at times.

Their prices are reasonable, their chips and tortillas are fresh, they have a variety of tortillas to chose from for your burritos and their meats are tender to the taste. Now this is what I call a "hole-in-the-wall-heaven!!"
author: Ms. Hala A.

description: I had the chicken super burrito.  It was ok, but disappointing since I've had Dos Toros in NY many times, which is supposedly modeled after Gordo.  I would much prefer Dos Toros over Gordo as it features much fresher and more flavorful ingredients.
author: Josh Q.

description:
Popped into Gordo  5 minutes before closing after a Thursday Nightlife at the Academy of Sciences. 
Yummy, easy, burritos and quesadillas. 
Guys were super nice even though they were closing up shop.
Wolfed 'em down in 5 minutes or less in the car wearing my favorite pashmina. 

Next morning on the way to work, car & pashmina reek of burrito. Classy all the way around.
author: Maggie M.

description: besides this business having quality food theres much more behind the walls staff are being treated unfairly such as not being paid overtime,sick days are not paid on top of that tips are handle by owner and management i know all this because i use to work at this place, people dont support these.. irs invaders
author: Jose F.

description:
Definitely a good plate to grab a burrito in the Inner Sunset.  Tortillas are warmed up (with cheese if you want it) before the burrito is made.  Good black beans, carne asada and pollo were both tasty.  Pico de Gallo had a good onion-y slightly spicy flavor, though I did add a little bit of hot sauce, so that added to it too of course.  Guacamole was a little watery looking, but tasted good once it was in the burrito and mixed in with everything else.

Friendly service, cheap ($6.24) burrito, comfortable bench seats.  I'm full but not stuffed, and will certainly be back here next time a burrito craving hits!

(P.S.  They also have tacos and quesadillas...maybe next time?)
author: Lindsay B.

description:
Great location, right by Golden Gate Park (a nice place to take your food and have a picnic).  Too bad it was raining on the day of our visit.  If you aren't familiar with this area, be warned:  parking is VERY scarce.

Burritos are good:  delicious, lean carnitas were the best part of mine.  All the other fillings are pretty standard.  The hot sauce is the green variety, which I don't like as much as the red.

Gordo's isn't fond of veggies.  The only kind available are in the pico de gallo.
author: Raina S.

description: As with all the Gordos in San Francisco, you can't beat the delicious quesadillas, burritos and tacos for the money.  The service is fast, and the carnitas will BLOW YOUR MIND.  While it can be tricky to find parking in the area, this might be my favorite Gordos in the local chain - try the carnitas quesadilla, with everything - and add some beans and rice!
author: Virginia B.

description:
What can I say? I freaking love Gordo's. I love their street tacos, I love their burritos, I love the workers. I love, you guys. In fact, I might have to go there now because I have taco fever. Also, I lived in southern california for 6+ years, so I feel like my taco-opinion is fairly legit. 

Mmm tacos! Eat them now!!!

edit: I totally ended up going there like an hour later.  My super burrito was amazeballs.
author: Lisa N.

description: Quick, easy, cheap, and HELLA GOOD. I go for the boiled chicken quesadilla (crispy, fatty, HUUUGE, and good!) and have them add the sour cream and fresh guacamole. In, out, and satisfied.
author: Hannah Y.

description:
Awesome Taqueria in the Inner Sunset.  I'm chomping down on 1/2 of my Super Carnitas Burrito I got last night.  Okay, so I'm one of those people that cuts their burrito in half.  Why?  'cuz they are way to big for me to eat in one sitting.  PLUS, serious - so I really need that big old spinach log of tortilla goodness in my belly at once?  

Ingredients are always fresh.  Chicken is awesome, as is the Carnitas.  I always go super to get the extra goodies on it.  Both their red and green sauces are great - and if you are a hot sauce super fan like I am, I always have them throw in two extra reds and two extra greens so I have some for my Chips, AND to pour over my burrito (look out for the next day tho - it can hurt coming out).

Parking sucks - FYI.  But the burritos don't.  Oh, and the chips are great.  I always get an extra bag to go with my 1/2 burrito I eat for lunch the next day.  Just a little extra advice for you to do with what you will.
author: Jason I.

description:
San Francisco has a lot of places to eat burritos when it's 2 AM and you're too drunk to know the difference. Gordo's caters to the more discriminating patron, and they preserve this dignity by closing at 11 PM. Personally, I like to bookend my night with burritos, and this is how I start. 

They have a small menu, and all of their burritos are good. Even the simple bean burrito is tasty. The fare is lighter and less greasy than other high-throughput burrito places. The service is fast and the prices are fair.
author: Lou S.

description:
Super Burrito is delicious! There is usually a long line whenever I seem to be in there but they workers keep the line moving at a decent speed. 

If you don't mind a short wait I would recommend eating their great food!
author: Marlene M.

description:
Oooo Gordo, you were good!

I've been hearing about you for a while now from our neighbors who enjoy your delectable burritos just about every Saturday night. Well, living in Marin, I wasn't sure when I'd find myself in the area to sample the goods... but WAHOO! for the Academy of Sciences Nightlife, 'cuz I found myself hungry and close to you! 

I had a pretty basic burrito - regular size with regular tortilla, black beans, rice, cheese, chicken, guac, green sauce - and it was gobbled up within minutes. Made me wish I'd gotten the larger size! 

All other members of my party were equally satisfied by their choices (bean & cheese, another chicken, chile verde). Pretty darn fabulous.
author: Liz K.

description: Really juicy, flavorful tacos, not to mention great value for the price.  For about $5 you get two solid sized tacos (same fillings as a street taco, but a little bigger and folded sideways).  Really hits the spot after running around in the park.  I tried their carnitas, but was eyeing "all meat" for next time.
author: Elaine S.

description:
The first time I've ever had boiled chicken in a burrito - boy, was it tender.

Their red salsa was so good, I wanted to grab the bowl and start drinking it. I can't decide if I like their salsa or Papalote's better.

The perfect way to conclude an afternoon of frolicking at Baker Beach.
author: Jen L.

description:
Today was my fourth day at my new job, which happens to be next door to Gordo's. Like right next door. Like, we share a hallway, and every time I walk down this hallway, I pass Gordo's side door and catch a whiff of all the yummy food inside. So, incidentally, today was my second day of work at my new job during which I have eaten at Gordo's.

The menu is really simple; burritos, tacos, and quesadillas. Both times, I ordered the regular bean and cheese burrito (with refried beans, because I'm always heath conscious), no salsa, plus sour cream and red sauce (enchilada sauce, maybe?). For what they were, they were delicious! The tortillas were nice and toasty, and the beans were perfect. I have a thing for refried beans. My grandma makes the best ones, and I'm always judging the beans of others. Gordo's beans pass the test. 

My only complaint is that chips cost extra. Not that the burritos themselves aren't big enough, but I'm messy, and I like having chips to clean up the burrito filling I inevitably spill.
author: Vanessa R.

description:
Fast, cheap, and pretty good in the context of Mexican food within the Sunset. Worth the 3.5 star rating it has, but I'll give it three as the one angle where it beats the other Mexican places in the Sunset is on account of being the cheapest. 

I had the regular chicken burrito, with pinto beans, rice, and tomatillo. I'm normally not a tomatillo person, but as pico was my only other choice on salsa, tomatillo it was.

Overall, I prefer La Fonda or L'Avenida for Mexican food in the Sunset due to their larger menu, better selection of meats, and the fact that they actually have a choice of salsa as compared to Gordo's effectively nonexistent selection. And while I do like the cheap prices at Gordo's, you get what you pay for in a 10" tortilla rather than the 12" that is my standard fare. 

I'll purposefully not compare Gordo's to Mexican outside the Sunset as I think it's basically pointless to do so there aren't so many people coming to the Sunset specifically for the Mexican food, instead if you live here, it's like I said, quick, cheap, and pretty good.
author: Chris S.

description:
I have been here twice and each time was disappointed. Sloppy burritos...and I mean the assembly, not the style. It's not hard to make a burrito and wrap it in a piece of foil, but for some reason I can't seem to get one that doesn't fall apart or isn't folded over on top of itself in the foil. You have to see it to understand how illogical this is.

Food quality...meh. There's a great place right around the corner instead.

I know a few people insist on going here, but I get the sense it's more for the GGP tourists who get tired of walking.
author: Scot B.

description: Growing up in the Richmond, I was accustomed to Gordo's for a good burrito to satisfy my hunger. The prices are still cheap and you can never go wrong with a super burrito. Eating here also made me realize the huge difference in burrito culture between San Francisco and San Diego. While I have been used to crispy grilled tortillas filled with meat and cheese, it's nice to have a steamed tortilla burrito stuffed with beans, meat, and rice without it coming from Chipotle. It was fast, cheap, good, and filling - everything that I look for in a quick meal. I also must have seen like five cops stop by here for a burrito; must be a favorite place of law enforcement as well.
author: Bailey Z.

description:
Two tacos = a whole meal for ~ $4.  And the food is GREAT.  Simple, limited menu, but really fresh ingredients, everything made to order, and rich, authentic flavors.  Their salsa are excellent, too.

Small space, great spot to grab a bite, or to go.
author: Fred W.

description:
Gordo's burrito is my "go to burrito" outside of the Mission.  I can't help but order the bean and cheese burrito with everything and the green hot sauce.  There is something about the simplicity of this burrito that has me coming back.  My BF always get the carnitas burrito.  I like how they chop the carnitas before tossing it into the burrito.  The burritos are so filling and inexpensive.  Chips are like $1.50...don't mind paying for them.  

Back in high school, I would get the carne asada quesadilla, which is like a smaller burrito, without the rice...and grilled.  It too is delicious and satisfying.  On the occasional sunny SF day, I'll grab burritos with the BF and head to the park.  Very nice!

The service is always fast and nice! The place is super clean, and I've never had a problem with grabbing a table.
author: Lesliegh H.

description:
Not all Gordo's are created equal.

I made this discovery the other day when picking up a quick bite for lunch.  What used to be a tiny hole in the wall has doubled in size which now caters to wandering hipsters, locals, and tourists alike.

The layout is equally confused, with two registers on either side of the counter, a production line of grilled serving as a backdrop.  On a busy day, the line loses its shape like a pool of refried beans.

The last time I went, the guy in line in front of me was blind.  He didn't have it easy.

I ordered the most simple Gordo burrito, the relatively snack-sized bean and cheese.  The rice was lacking a little flavor, and the beans were severely undercooked, so much so that I probably should have returned it to the kitchen.

I guess it just goes to show that what you serve in quantity can have a detrimental affect on it's quality.
author: Tony L.

description:
Came here during half-time for the NBA Finals and I was very satisfied.

Nice, clean spot with quick service. Cheaper than Chipotle and just as filling. The Carnitas Burrito was delicious. You have to pay for some extras, but nothing ridiculous. Plenty of free toppings to customize your burrito.

Highly recommend this place for a quick, tasty burrito attack!
author: William D.

description:
This place has yet to disappoint me.  If you're craving a burrito from the mission, but you don't want to venture all the way out there, this is a good substitute.

I usually get the Super Burrito with rice, beans, beef, tomatoes, hot sauce, and sometimes guacamole.  It's reasonably priced, it tastes good, and it's filling.

They also have bottomless fountain drinks in addition to the bottled ones.
author: Ken H.

description:
How have I not reviewed this?  Almost got totally Gordo on these because they are so good.... I realized the super burrito was simply an extra scoop of beans and rice, and that was just padding.  But the steak is awesome, and not boiled like some places... it is cooked constantly throughout the day.  They have multiple types of tortillas, I like me some spinach.  They wrap em tight, have fresh made and DELICIOUS tortilla chips that make you feel somewhat guilty with the oil seeping onto the bag.... but look past it friends.  Gordo rocks.

Better than Papalote in my book, which consistently gets the best ratings... I can't go more than a week without one.
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description:
Insert some kind of factoid about how the number of burritos I've eaten here could reach the moon and back. 

And despite eating all these burritos over the years, Gordos is just average.  It's the Lab mix of burritos.  The VW Jetta of Mexican food.  Average.  Not great.  Not bad.  Okay.  Just okay.  

You see, San Franciscans have more Mexican food eateries than they know what to do with, especially in the Mission but honestly every neighborhood seems to have at least one or two taquerias.  Therefore, it's sink or swim and while Gordo's rarely sinks, it hardly floats to the top.  If only La Cornetta would open in the Sunset....
author: Jacob M.

description:
Pretty standard mexican food. Nothing too special.

It's cheap and decent quality. You wont leave feeling like you just ate a ton of lard. 

Very simple menu and fresh ingredients. Food could be slightly bland depending on what you taste is.

They melt their sliced cheese in the steamer with the tortilla when  you order a burrito...cool!
author: Mario W.

description:
This place was pretty good.  Solid sized burritos.

But the only thing I can remember is driving around the neighborhood in search of a burrito place called "Lardos", hahahaha. 

Thanks Ashley M.
author: Chelsea C.

description:
So, they have chips....they have cheese...they have beans....they have meats on the ready...

So why won't they serve me nachos? They have all of the ingredients!

They staff are always nice and apologetic about the nacho situation, and the price is right.If I could have nachos after work at the Shamrock, they would be seeing my face twice weekly.
author: Erin G.

description: Average tasting food. They charge for chips. Might have to wait in line. They do have moderate seating. The location is nice, right next to ggp.
author: Alex C.

description:
It's Saturday evening and I haven't eaten anything all day except for an English muffin.  I was starving, and headed to Yancy's to watch the game.  The logical side of me took over and said "get some food before you start drinking."

I parked, looked around me, and saw Gordo.  I was set for the night.

Super steak burrito + guac + sour cream - beans = food coma heaven.  Wolfed it down and followed with a pear cider.

All while Lebron was being a beast on the court.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Gordo is my 2nd fav place in the city (behind El Farolito). I usually stick with the Carne Asada burrito -- which is seasoned so beautifully, but occasionally I venture to the corn quesadilla, which is the best I've had anywhere. Gordo is much cleaner and less crowded than anyone you'd find in the Mission, but you do lose the ambiance of "cheap Mexican" that you find at others -- your choice. 

This location is the best, but the one on Geary and 19th isn't far behind.
author: David M.

description:
Typically when I think of cheap Mexican food, I think of Chipotle...yes I know, what standards. But after a morning at the de Young, the bf and I were hungry and found this place; he remembered that it's supposed to be amazing, so we went in.

I ordered a chicken quesadilla and he got the chicken super burrito. Man, that was GOOD food. It was crazy cheap too! My queso wasn't just chicken and melted cheese, but had salsa in it, which tasted fantastic.

Only complaint is that the salsa fresca hangs out in plastic containers in the fridge and didn't have the best flavor. But otherwise, really good!
author: Emilia S.

description:
After traipsing through Golden gate park all day, my friends and I were famished and decided to eat cheap. I swear, Gordos has been here since my college days back in the early 80's though I have no recollection of ever eating here.
The food is good, nothing really extraordinary..no station for extra salsa or other condiments, not enough seating for parties over three (there were five of us). It's an assembly line tacqueria and the menu is simple. I had the regular chicken burrito, refritos, guacamole, salsa picante, etc. and it was good. I had them throw in jalapenos because the salsa looked tamed. Not a great drink selection (no tea!!) but it was $4.95 plus tax so it was a cheap nosh.
author: michael s.

description: Where is the horchata man?  I can't believe that don't sell it here!  But the burritos are huge and at a good price.  If you are like me and dislike whole beans, be sure to request your refried beans before they start making your mountain of a burrito.  Chips cost .75c.  They are located just across the street from Golden Gate Park, so you can just cross the street and get a bite.  Ariba.
author: Michelle M.

description:
I don't know why, but every week I come back to this place. It might just because I work over at the de Young and this is close by, but I don't think so.

I always get either the chicken or beef super burrito, no beans, everything else + sour cream. Delicious. I've had some pretty bad run-ins with burritos (so bad I don't even want to re-live them, lest I lose my taste for Gordo) and Gordo came into my life.

DEFINITELY do not come here more than you need to, but it is definitely worth it as a quick bite before work, or anything of the like. =]
author: Jeffrey Z.

description:
Pluses:
*Friendly service
*Good chips
*Good guacamole
*Convenient location - next to a main artery of Golden Gate Park
*Quick food
*Tables + chairs to dine at if the weather is too cold.

Minuses:
*Chips + Salsa - you pay extra for these, sign of the times.
*No hot sauce on the table

***

I had a chicken taco.  Was okay.
author: Cathy K.

description: really a ZERO.. a visit by the Department of Health is what is needed here.
author: Roxanne P.

description:
I love their rice. This is what kept me coming back for more. 

Rice, salsa, and beans with grilled chicken. Yum. :)

Fresh and tasty.
author: Stephanie J.

description: Yummy burritos for a good price. Was $7 for a super carnitas burrito with chips. Yum! Good fast service, will be coming back here if in the neighborhood.
author: Kayla C.

description: the best chile verde burrito I've ever had in my life! the meat is always tender and service is very speedy. this is your stop for a quick and cheap SF style burrito. I highly recommend the chile verde, the carnitas, and the grilled chicken! if you're really hungry, get the "all meat". it's every kind of meat they have wrapped in a massive burrito with your regular salsa, beans, rice, etc.
author: Kevin L.

description: Only giving this 1 star because I can't give it 0. Got terrible food poisoning starting 3 hours after I ate and even had to cancel a flight the next day because I was so sick. Couldn't eat anything for almost a week after. Will never come here again.
author: Adam S.

description:
We've been Gordo's devotees for 15+ years and it's biggest defender.  I've basically lost friends over the Gordo's vs. La Avenida debate.  Well, that's not true (the lost friends part), but our allegiance is true.  

Two years ago, a 5-star rating would've been a no brainer.  Problem is, the price has been on meteoric rise over ths time.  Just two years ago, my family of 4 would eat for under $20.  Now it's something like $26.  And . . . my perception is that they've been systematically skimping on the meat of late as well.  And I know for certain that my last super was way smaller than usual. My wife had ordered it and I had to ask her if she was sure she ordered super and not regular.  She was sure, so hopefully this was an aberration (it better have been).

Still, the food here is delicious.  I love the grilled chicken and carnitas, and the chile verde plate is awesome too.  Still a deal, I guess, although I know there are plenty of cheaper burritos to be had around town.
author: Chuck P.

description:
As I have believe that my first Gordos experience as a young child in Richmond may have changed my life forever, I found it only right that they be the first place I review on yelp. I will be the first to say that this review may be slightly biased but heartfelt nonetheless. 

I eat a TON of burritos and I would take gordos over them all any day of the week. The steamed in cheese, the fresh fillings, the amazing hot sauce! I am so confused as to why the reviews are not better. I will just leave some small hints below hoping that it will help the nonbelievers out there. 

1. Get an extra side of their amazing hot sauce. It will take it up to a whole other level. 
2. Ask for extra cilantro. They have a mound of freshly chopped cilantro in the cooler and will pile it on upon request. 
3. Extra cheese. Always. They have the best cheese and it is melted right onto the tortilla to latch onto all the rice and beans...mmmm... 
4. If your calories are not an obstacle than go with the quesadilla. It is like a cheesy burrito fried on the flat top and filled with salsa and goodness. SO GOOD. 

I love you Gordos. I always will.
author: Allison B.

description: I remember trying the Gordo's on Clement years ago and not being super impressed, but gave it another try with a Gilt City voucher. And the burrito was very very good. I'm not a huge burrito fan actually, but this one was awesome-not too wet, which I hate, yet not dry. The chicken was delicious. I had my doubts seeing it scooped out of what appeared to be dingy chicken water, but apparently that kept it moist and super fresh. The cheese was also good, nice and melted, the whole thing kept its heat  for a long time after getting it to go. The ingredients were spread out uniformly (clumpy ingredients are another burrito pet peeve of mine, really do I want all the hot sauce in one mouthful, all the beans in another--no!!). Delicious. Chips and salsa were also good, and came with a really large half pint of salsa.
author: D R.

description: The super pollo is the way to go with extra hot sauce, and black beans.....man, I drive across the city, bike, bus it whatever it takes to get one of these super grubbin burritos...I love this place, great prices and good food always go together...
author: Ryan A.

description:
Gordo's is an "a-ok" Mexican food spot.

I really enjoy their tacos, but everything else seems sub-par to other restaurants in the.

The one thing that I really appreciate about Gordo's is their meat, just really well flavored and perfectly juicy. Both pollo and carne asada have been amazing.

On the other hand.. their burritos are a bit of a mess, literally, they fall apart as you're eating them, causing you to eat like an animal to try to save ingredients from spilling out or getting all over yourself.  I don't know if its the cheap tortillas they buy or if they use too many wet ingredients, but its frustrating.  They even wrap the darn thing in tin-foil to keep it together, and that still doesn't work.
Furthermore, they charge $1.50 for chips and salsa... and in disproportionate amounts.... 
Drinks are also pricey.

Overall, I only come here if my friends have already made plans, otherwise I don't come on my own.
author: Jaclyn O.

description: A-OK is right about right. The food is okay for a burrito place, but there are better options. And ironically, the food at this place is made by a bunch of dudes behind the counter that as mentioned elsewhere are not the friendliest. Ironic because, very near here is a burrito place where there's a bunch of women behind the counter and I definitely feel the love a whole lot more when I'm there. Just saying. Do you want your food served with lover or attitude? Like water for chocolate.
author: Ken L.

description:
Growing up in SF one has to be somewhat of a connoiseur when it comes to burritos. Our beloved city is known for authentic burritos leaving us very spoiled. 

Gordo's is franchise with numerous locations in the city and perhaps the Bay Area. I went with a couple of my co-workers to kinda celebrate an early birthday. My co-workers swear on this place, up-and-down like 6 o'clock. I've told them that it is good but I've had better. No argument on my end, just the facts ma'am.

I was gonna order an "all-meat" but when I got to the counter I realized that having all the meat mixed up together didn't seem like such a good idea. So I opted for a super carnitas burrito (since I didn't eat anything all day). I usually get chicken but since it is Lent, I decided to splurge. The burrito was good. The best thing about Gordo's is that everything is fresh. The bad thing...no horchata.
author: Ivan F.

description:
Gordo offers the fastest fast food in San Francisco. Quite possibly, in the solar system. 

Before you can say "Un burrito regular de pollo cocido, por favor, con frijoles pintos, guacamole, tomate, y un poco caliente" -- heck, before you can get to "regular" -- the dude has rolled and wrapped it with a few subtle flicks of the wrist, and chucked it over to the cashier.  The whole time he's staring at the wall behind you, slack-jawed, like he's in a trance. 

These guys are in the zone 24/7. Scary good.

As to the burrito itself, this, for me, is a good, consistent, fallback S.F. burrito. I'm not going to argue with the people who say they're underwhelmed because they're not biting into a some sort of gustatory mariachi band. This is the Sunset District, OK? Fog, gray, toned down, dialed back -- that's how we roll out here. The Mission is the Mission, the Avenues are the Avenues. Cultural relevance, my brother.
author: Douglas G.

description:
I will always love Gordos.  I know it is not the best, but it is consistent, clean, and always hits the spot.  I order the carnitas super burrito, and cut it in half, then save the other half for lunch the next day.  

When I'm not too hungry, I do like the quesadillas they make with corn tortillas.  They are smaller, and they grill them so they get a bit crispy on the outside. I ask them to put in a few pinto beans and it is the perfect snack.  

I like the green salsa, and do not like the fresh tomato/cilantro/onion mix, but they will leave it off if you ask them to.   The guys who work here are nice, but seem harassed. I love to flirt a little with my very lame Espanol (thanks, Lincoln H.S.!).  This gets a nicely made burrito that is abundantly stuffed.  

If I ever find the perfect burrito place, I will give it 5 stars, but in the meantime, you should consider my four stars as pretty stellar.
author: Hannah Lee H.

description: Solid, good daily special (today was al pastor taco at $1.25 a pop) free refills, good salsa, flavorful, and fast. I wish they included chips. Not as shocking a display as Pancho Villa, but when your in the 'hood, go with the flow.
author: Andrew K.

description:
I love Gordos.  Plain and simple.

I used to frequent the 24th and Clement location when I lived in the Richmond, now that I'm in the sunset the 9th Avenue one is slightly closer.

But anyway, for my money nothing beats the value-for-your-buck of Gordos when it comes to delicious, quick and semi-healthy food. 

All the reviews I'm reading with people complaining about the lack of authenticity at this place seem either unfounded or biased.  I've been to quite a bit of different burrito places in the Mission and well, they just don't have that savory feel of Gordos.  Plus, I am not a big fan of having to worry about my car getting broken into or shot at randomly whilst in the Mission.  The only thing you need to worry about in the Sunset is the lack of parking, and that won't kill you (physically).

You can always ask for extra whatever without fear of being looked at as-if you are thief.  Want a bit more of that fresh salsa? Go ahead! They'll throw on an extra scoop for ya.  Want another helping of beans? By all means!

The portions are extremely generous.  Five bucks gets you a massive burrito that isn't going to fall apart on you while you eat.   The quesadillas are grilled to perfection and you always end up savoring the bread as much as the insides.  

And ever since they started taking credit cards, it has made my decision to eat Gordos that much easier!
author: Serge S.

description: The price is right ($4.45 for a regular burrito) and the food is filling and makes for a fast meal but the flavors are bland and uninspiring. I took one bite and immediately walked to the counter and asked for two containers of the green hot sauce because the burrito was so bland. Each bite required a dab of the hot sauce and even then the burrito was made palatable but not not delicious. The hot sauce was mild. Overall, the food is cheap and filling but not enough to evoke any kind of craving.
author: Melissa K.

description:
Pretty decent tasting burrito.

I like the hot sauce, it's a little zesty.  The meat and the rest of the filling has some flavor.  Not the best I've had though.

The place is pretty nice to sit down and enjoy your meal.
author: Sam T.

description:
I started coming to this Gordo because it's a lot closer to where I live than the one on Geary, which I've visited the most. Some of the same employees split time between the stores, so if you see a familiar face, it's not because you're being a racist Anglo.

What can I say? It's Gordo. They make the burrito quickly, will basically do whatever you want, and there aren't any frills. What's not to like? It's not the best burrito, but for some reason I like the actual location better than the other two. And the homeless guy who hangs out outside will actually let you buy him a burrito rather than demanding money.
author: John S.

description:
Food: I tried a chicken burrito. I wish it had more flavor, to me it tasted pretty bland. The size was also not overwhelming, it was big enough though to fill my stomach for lunch. 

Price: Prices are cheap. A burrito is only around $4. They also had tacos for under $3. My only peeve is that chips are extra!!!

Atmosphere: Nothing special, better to order to go.

Service: Fast service, there was no line when I went in. 


Location: :Located right on 9th ave off of Irving/Lincoln. Street parking can be difficult but the 71 bus and N Judah run right along here.
author: Miss H K.

description:
Gordos has been a favorite of mine since I was a kid. It's not super special, but always reliable and delicious. If you're feeling adventurous ask them to make you a burrito with two tortillas. They'll look at you like you're crazy, but each bite is like the end of the burrito. 
The salsa and quac here is amazing, so I think maybe even over the burritos that's my favorite part. It's cash only though, which is pretty lame.
author: Ash S.

description:
I eat here about once a week.
Chili Verde rocks
Nice people
Fresh Fresh Fresh
Gordo=Fat (yummy)!

I wonder how many times a day they say the word pinto?
author: Pug P.

description: They will fry the hell out of your corn tortilla. And you will weep with happiness.
author: Rita C.

description:
I have never eaten a fog-bound burrito or taco anywhere where I craved it again. Gordo is kind of the gold standard of the sub-standard. Eat here only if it's The Burrito Of Least Resistance, i.e., within 2-3 blocks of your pad.

There seems to be an cruel, invisible barrier surrounding The Mission that won't let cheap and truly tasty Mexican food out. And by tasty I mean, you see lots of Mexicans eating it. Not just Johnny Baltimore getting his first taste of mild salsa. 

All over South San Francisco and San Mateo, delicious tacos are being made. Taco trucks abound. Why then are there no *actually* good San Francisco taquerias above Market Street?
author: Jeremy W.

description:
_dudes are dicks that work there
_bland food
_YOU HAVE TO PAY for chips and salsa
_there cheese sucks
_my roomate loves this damn place.....i hate it.
_i do like the painting inside (on the left when you walk in)
_sorry Gordo
author: Jrno O.

description:
Just good burritos. I have a super burrito with carnitas, sour cream and guacamole and I've got no complaints, the staff seem friendly and the location is super considering it's just off the 44 and N. It's not the nicest place to sit but then it's best to just grab and go since burritos are, of course, the best takeaway food. I've never seen a big queue in there either which is rare with good food places.

I love the fact the menu is so simple, just a few items for offer so it's not too complicated for a burrito newcomer such as myself, they have a good range of drinks and a soda fountain too. Not much else to say really.
author: Adam S.

description:
Daayyyyymmmmnnn,

This place is hellllla good. But not as good as the Clement one. I always go with carnitas, guacamole, and lots of hot sauce.  Grab a super burrito or quesadilla and you're ready to go!!
author: Dennis L.

description:
gordo's is an essential part of the richmond. they are not the best burrito/quesidilla I've ever had but they sure are still pretty damn good. better than lots of places i've tried in the mission. carnitas burrito is the best. the regular burritos are massive. the super burritos are good for two meals or a hefty appetite.

also, gordos is dirt cheap. and fresh and delicious. i feel better about my life knowing i'm within a few blocks of a good burrito. even in the richmond. thank you, gordos.
author: Becky B.

description: I got a regular chicken and black bean burrito.  It was ok- slightly better than Moe's Southwest Grill. The prices are good- so maybe at some point I would eat here again, but with so many other fantastic choices- probably not.
author: Christy L.

description: They Have the best Burrito in a cheap affordable price and their salsa for the chips, the flavor has improved too and their soda fountain is always fresh not like other's there is no bubbles into it...
author: Qween_Gie S.

description:
I have been coming here since I was in 8th grade and I still LOVE this place. I have never tried their burritos, so I'm basically only going to write about the quesadilla.

Honestly, I have never had a better quesadilla from anywhere else than this place. My order normally consists of a Super Quesadilla with grilled chicken, rice, tomatoes, sour cream, and extra extra extra hot sauce. Trust me, the extra extra extra hot sauce (green sauce) makes everything taste 10X better than how it originally taste. Not saying it's bad without it though, it's just a whole lot better.

Their quesadilla is made with a flour tortilla with a slice of cheese in it. They then place it on the grill allowing the cheese to melt onto the tortilla, which makes it taste a lot better in my opinion. The tortilla is also then a bit crispy which is an added plus.

Quick Service and great food, what much more can you ask for ? I've been a fan of this place and still am.

Why no 5 stars? It's because of all the times I go there, they always charge me different prices. It seems to me that they like to sneak in extra charges. For example: today I noticed they charged me an extra 65 cents for guacamole when I never got any. I would've said something but I figure since I'm a long time customer, I wouldn't mind letting them keep the extra change.

Overall, try this place out. Lots of seating inside, but parking may be hard. My order of Super quesadilla normally costs me around 6-7 dollars. Nothing more.

P.S: I can't help but emphasize getting EXTRA EXTRA EXTRA hot sauce. When I tell them to add extra hot sauce, I think I actually say "extra" five times haha. But trust me, you won't regret it.
author: Garrick L.

description:
Like every other tacqueria outside the Mission, these guys don't get it.  The secret to a good burrito is first and foremost, GRILL the tortilla!  Never, ever steam that skin.  The second thing is to use avocado instead of green water.  The third rule of burritos is you do not talk about...  Wait.  The third rule is to cut the gristle off the beef before serving it.

One out of 3 for old Big's.
author: Morey S.

description:
You know what grinds my gears?  Taquerias that don't have those big ol' jugs of freshly made Horchata and those different Melon juices-Fresca.   Gordo's is a mini chain in the Richmond and Sunset district.  Food wise...It's just Okay, and out in those two neighborhoods you just don't have much of a Taqueria selection.   It's usually pretty busy during the lunch hour.  It's a good place for a quick, sloppy, but tasty burrito.  Other than that, I doubt this place would survive in the Mission district where the REAL Taquerias that have HORCHATA  are. 

BTW, This is my very first review.  Booyah!  How'd I do?  I want cool points.
author: aubrey L.

description:
This place is great!! For the negative reviews, come on?? This place is a Taqueria and nothing more. The food is good, the service is effective, and the quality is all good. 

So for all of those who want to rip on the service, go to a sit down joint. 
If you want a burrito in the Mission, go to the freakin' mission. Hopefully your wallet is still in your pocket by the time you make it to your mission Taqueria!!! :) 

Long story short, this is a neighborhood restaurant. It has served the area well for many years and continues to do so. 

Oh yeah, for the girl who one starred this place who hangs out at the tattoo parlor, get a clue- I have seen some of the folks who hung out there and let's just say that ,well, never mind. That tattoo joint is one seedy place
author: Pete G.

description: We ordered two super burritos and wow they were really quite heavy burritos. My bf didn't like his saying it was too bland for him. I agree that my super burrito which I ordered with guacamole and sour cream (extra cost) was not overly flavorful. But that's ok because I get tired of overly flavored burritos. I thought the carnitas itself was flavorful. I found the overall  blandness welcoming and satisfying and for just under $5 I thought it was a good deal.
author: Helen L.

description:
In San Fran magazine's 2006 Reader's Poll, the top 3 taquerias were Pancho Villa (no surprise), La Taqueria (naturally), and...Gordo's?  Well, in that case, I'd better give it a try.

A common complaint in the Yelp reviews is that you have to pay for chips and salsa.  But seeing as the Mrs and I could get both get by on a $4.55 carnitas super burrito, it's still one of the cheapest places around.

The restaurant itself is a small, unassuming little place with a barebones menu.  Surprisingly uncrowded for lunchtime...maybe the fog keeps 'em away.  The community bulletin board and leather-strap benches are a nice touch.

As for the food, burritos are solid but nothing exceptional.  I have a feeling that the reason this place did so well in the reader's poll is because it's a Bay Area chain, hence its gravitational pull is artificially extended.
author: Wes M.

description:
The first thing that comes to mind when I think of this place is... YIKES!

My food was COVERED in grease/oil!!!!!!!!!!!  Are they trying to kill their customers!!!???  Is it really necessary to drown my food in oil when you're cooking it?  I had to dab my food with napkins and it still didn't soak up half of the oil.  I ended up throwing most of my food in the trash.

These days we put so much emphasis on what McDonald's and KFC are doing but somebody should really check into all these Mom and Pop places too....
author: Jess R.

description: This has been one of my favorite Mexican restaurants in SF for over 10 years. Great prices, quality and quantity! My suggestion: order a super steak QUESADILLA...it will be just like a burrito, but with a little extra crunch w/ super melty cheese. Still around $4-$6 for a massive meal, after all these years!
author: Alix D.

description:
They have a basic menu, and ridiculously simple process for making burritos.  That's pretty much all they do, is crank out burritos!  But man, these guys rock.  I've been eating here for almost 7 years and its consistently one of the best burritos you can get.  Fast, cheap, solid!

Get the super carnitas burrito w/ black beans and guacamole.  You won't be disappointed!
author: Steve S.

description:
Edible burritos w/ steamed tortilla wrappers.  A minimal taqueria.  Basic Mexican cuisine is hard to screw up.

One of the chefs has a hard-on against Caucasian males.  I ordered a super veggy burrito w/ black beans and guacamole and was given a brown beaner with salsa.  I turned it right back and reiterated my first choice.  The chef said, "Are you sure?", as if it were my fault, and then spooned out a niggardly small "Super".

The next time I went in, the same chef avoided catching my eye as I waited to place an order and let me stand around for thirty seconds contemplating the futility of revisiting bad restaurants.

In sum, edible food but bad vibes.  Classify this place as, "History".

[EDIT:  Upgraded to three stars because it provides a handicapped accessible restroom to anyone who wants to use it, whether or not they shop there.  The Sunset is crammed with Asian eateries of the, "Restrooms for Customer Use Only", chain and anyone going against the NIMBY excretion dissuasion deserves a kudo.]
author: Paul Q.

description:
Gordos is the kind of mexican food that gets you by. Not Authentic, nothing special about it...it's just convenient enough for you to enjoy until scientists develop the technology to teleport us to the mission. 

The service is slow at times because of specific people having to be meticulous about how their burrito is made (Beans on the left, chease on the right), What the fuck difference does it make? I've come there for years it surprises me that they ask me what I want on the item I always get...there is no huge time gap in between the times I have ordered from them....they've seen me enough. Not that I need a sense of community or anything....it's just odd. 

I still give them three stars though, mainly because I don't like walking far for food....it always makes for a good alternative on those cold sunset nights.
author: James J.

description: The burritos and tacos here are both pretty good.  The meats are tasty and fresh and the price isn't bad either.  Definitely on the heavier side but what do you expect from a burrito?
author: Brian T.

description:
This isn't the best burrito place in San Francisco, but it's in such close proximity to me that I'm here all the time. Fresh and hot, it's exactly what the burrito doctor called for.

But......I had one of the grossest burrito experience from a burrito here. A few years ago I was going to see Belle & Sebastian. I knew I wouldn't have time to have dinner so I bought a burrito here earlier in the afternoon so save and scarf down after the show. The show was awesome but I came home and wolfed down the burrito after heating it up in the microwave. I never ate a burrito so fast in my life but afterwards I felt gross. Like I got raped by a burrito and I was carrying an illegitimate burrito baby. It was really my fault, I shouldn't have eaten it so quickly. But to this day, the thought of a reheated burrito makes me sick.
author: Jackie I.

description:
Went to the Gem and Mineral show in GG Park on Saturday, but regretfully, didn't see any rock stars or rockers, nor was anyone stoned.  Anyway, we decided to get a bite to eat beforehand, but noticed that all the restaurants were packed from the nice weather.

Popped into Gordo Taqueria (had seen it on Yelp the other day) and got the standard by which I judge every burrito place I hit, a carne asada super burrito. 

The place was clean and the ingredients looked fresh.  The burrito was big, but the carne asada pieces were a little small and dry and could have been a bit more flavorful.  The cheese was a slice of unidentified white cheese laid into the burrito which later must have gone into the witness protection program since it completely disappeared once I took a bite.

The burrito was okay, but there was something about this burrito in general that just missed the mark.  Can't quite put my finger on it, but it just lacked that depth of flavor, that certain rich authentic burrito goodness that makes you crave it when you eat it.  Despite that, if you value trendy fresh taste in a burrito, you'll probably like this one.

For me, the overwelming flavor profile of this burrito from first bite is tart, fresh salsa.  Salsa, salsa, and more salsa.  Some people love that, I don't.  Other burritos I've had and craved have a different quality to them, a certain indescribable heavier depth of flavor, a magical melding of meat, bean, cheese and rice that just screams authentic.  This one was more reminiscent of La Salsa.    

Food is a funny thing as it's so subjective.  What's awesome for one person is just okay for another and vice versa.  In a place like SF with so many options, that's a beautiful thing.

Anyway, in the end, it just didn't do it for me.  Doesn't mean I might not go back someday, but eh, I've had better.  Portions were good and the place seemed clean and reasonable, so I'll be generous and give it three stars.
author: Roy N.

description:
Ugh.  Awful.  

The one redeeming factor:  it's cheap, and very efficient service.  

Otherwise, just gross.  

Much prefer Papalote.
author: Alex J.

description: Its good! BUT! I think it is weird that they used sliced cheese and melt it on the tortilla! I always like getting it 'super' because the guac and sour cream make it taste better.
author: Angela D.

description: Gordo's is a good place to go when you need a place close by and can't get to the Mission or the next best thing which is Chipotle's for me. I like the chicken burritos and the prices last time I went (years ago) weren't so bad. It's definitely not the best place I've had a burrito at (I wish they grilled the chicken a bit more and didn't put so much cilantro in their tomatoes) other than that, it's decent food and local.
author: Petra S.

description:
This is my go to place for a quick meal. $6 and out the door for a huge, delicious super burrito. If I'm not as hungry, I go with the quesadilla, which is tender/flakey/crispy/cheesy tortilla wrapped, burrito-style. I eat here about once a week, and it always delivers. 

Steak and carnitas are where it's at here for meat, though the carnitas are sometimes a bit dry. Everything is consistently tasty, and they don't skimp with the sour cream and guac if you ask. For Mexican food in SF, Gordo's is the best bang for your buck that I know of.
author: Eric P.

description:
While there are some things at Gordo that are below average, I always focus on the one thing i think they do right - Carnitas.  I think they have some of the most flavorful Carnitas around.  I am not one of those people who think that Carnitas should be wet and mushy.  I like them on the drier side with a little fat... closer to the crispy texture of chicharron than of pot roast.

My menu item of choice is the Carnitas Quesadilla.
author: Tony W.

description: Worst food as in too salty, overcooked, canned salsa and small portions.  Even worse than the food was the service from the obese sweaty bleached blond Latina checker girl at 5:30PM on Friday, May 10.  She even had a bigger attitude to match, wouldn't give or sell me tortilla chips even though I fed the tip jar directly in front of her.  They had two dozen little tortilla bags on the counter.  After i asked twice for a bag of chips, extra $$ or not, she puts me off and tells me the tortilla chips were inside the meal box.  I guess she doesn't know the difference between crispy tortilla chips in a little bag and soft steamed taco shells warped in aluminum foil. No stars for you!
author: Martin F.

description: great place for quick lunch. They are quick, food is tasty, price is excellent. I am satisfied with one chicken taco, which costs me $3.10. I haven't tried burritos, they look big. For fast food, Gordo is right one to go.
author: S P.

description:
I don't understand what people are talking about.  The tacos (the meats in particular) are rather bland.  I got the carnitas taco and beef/steak taco.  

I got full, but was not satisfied.  Y'all need to season your meats and salsa.  They don't even have extra hot sauce condiments out in case we need to spice up our foods more.  

I would go back again, however, because I'm just hoping their chicken items are more flavorful than the pig/cow ones
author: Grace M.

description:
I've been going to Gordo's since 2000. I think I've been to every one except the one in Albany.

So the burritos are what I go for here. One thing for sure, the food is always consistent. Okay, so it's not the Mission burritos, but just as tasty, less greasy. They also have the fizzy-est fountain Coke that I know of!

Standard Order:
Super Burrito
Grilled Chicken
Light on the pinto beans
Guacamole
Extra tomatoes
Extra hot sauce
Medium Coke
(sometimes I get the chips)

You watch them make the burrito, so you can make on the fly adjustments to the order if needed.

Have a Happy Burrito Day!
author: Alex A.

description:
I've been coming here for 10 years.  A couple years ago, they supersized the regular burrito (more rice, still no cheese) and jumbo sized the super burrito.  Wow, that's a lot of food for $5.  

Also, you know it's good when all the construction workers in the sunset send over a guy for a massive take out order at lunch.  

Faves:  
 - grilled chicken super burrito, black beans, salsa, sour cream, extra hot sauce.
 - carnitas burrito
 - steak quesadilla, salsa
 - taking any of the above for a picnic in the arboretum in Golden Gate Park
author: Olivia L.

description: I grew up eating here, but not this location. Parking is scant but I guess that goes for all Gordos locations. I absolutely love the burritos here!!! Fresh ingredients, fast service, and great flavors! I always get the carnitas burrito and it never fails to satisfy my burrito craving. The meat is tender and juicy, the rice is the perfect consistency along with the texture of the black beans, and the salsa is refreshing. DELICIOUS!
author: Lauren D.

description: MUST EAT HERE! this is by far one of the best places for burritos i have ever been!!!  Gordo's is the shiznit!!  used to work two blocks over and i was a regular at Gordo's for lunch.  Super Carnitas Burrito was there for me 5 days a week and i never got tired of it.  can put u to sleep but man, was it ever good!!  i wish the franchise would set up shop in LA and give all these crappy ass Taqueria's a run for their money...because they would!!!
author: Alejandro L.

description:
I used to work at the Academy of Sciences in Golden Gate Park so I used to come here to eat once in a while.  I'd say nothing special but one day I was working a free day and had no dinner.  Since I had to grab a quick dinner, I came to Gordo's for a quick bite.  Oh the horror!!

About an hour after I ate a burrito here, I started feeling a mild sore throat coming on me.  I didn't think much of it, I figured I was just coming down with something and it would be gone after I got some sleep. WRONG!! This was the most horredous soar throat I had ever.  I didn't know soar throats lasted that long, a little bit longer than a week.  I assume the culprit was something inside my burrito, most likely some guacomole they had out for a while or some sucka didn't wash their hand.  

Anyways, this is all speculation but I'm pretty damn sure it wasn't a coicidence that I got a raging soar throat after eating here right before they closed.
author: Jason Y.

description:
I've been here a couple of times. It's kind of just the get food and go kind of place to me. The food quality: good but average. Selection: good but average. I think you go here because you want something simple and predictable.

Times visited: 2
author: Amy L.

description:
Nearly forgot that I'd eaten here.  But then again, after those 3 weeks of hell, I'm surprised I remember anything at all.  

We roll up here, forget which day it was but I know for sure it was somewhere in between finals.  I think it was around lunch time.  Yes.  Because whilst we were there, office workers and other obligatory employed yet hungry people stood in line with lists generated from co-workers.  

I got a chicken super burrito.  Exciting, unpredictable, and new.  No.  But filling, comforting and tucking in neatly.  Yes.  

NOT Cash only.  

I think I miss the salsa bars of the other places.  The burrito was not...terrible.  But it could have been liberally doused with fresh salsa from the non-existent salsa bar instead on only Tapatio.  Or maybe I'm too optimistic.  Idealistic.  Prone to disappointment.  

The burrito was huge.  Yay.  The tortilla was steamed with the cheese, which I happen to like.  I don't like it loose and floppy but I do like it a little bit gummy and tightly bound.  It just looks so...right.  So correct.  Like there is order in the world.  If there were such a thing as a unified field theory, I think it would exist in a burrito.  If Einstein had been privileged to masticate such a tender tidbit, he would know the ether that makes up the universe.  

But, all in all, not something that I wake up thinking about.
author: Christina C.

description:
