description: This is probably the only Gordo's in the city which makes a decent burrito. The one on Geary use to be good but lately it's not even comparable to Taco Bell. Anyway if you can find parking on 9th and Irving, this place has good food.
author: Spooky B.

description: Best burrito you can get in the Sunset.  Period.
author: Carter Y.

description:
I had never been here before, even though I live a couple blocks away.  I have always frequented La Fonda's and the occasional tasty Mission Taqueria.  I went inside and the atmosphere was immediately stale.  The menu had about 10 items on it, as opposed to 20 or 30 at some places.  I ordered the  Bean and Cheese Super Burrito, and was dissappointed that I had to pay extra for chips.  I asked for salsa on the side and the little cup was only half full.  The cheese was not shredded, but they took 3 or 4 slices and melted it on to the tortilla.  Gross.  

Aside from the negatives, however, the food is cheap, the chips are great, and they give generous portions.  This will pretty much be a fall-back cheap taquearia-type situation, but I prbly won't go there again anytime soon.
author: Emily H.

description: I don't eat burritos too often. The reason why is contained in the name of this Taqueria. Which is to say, they are fattening. That being said, Gordo always does a good job. They're not as good as Cancun or some of the other places in the Mission but for the neighborhood it does the trick.
author: lazslo t.

description: The only place where I'll ever order chicken with my burrito (I ALWAYS go with steak). There's just something about the broth that the chicken sits in that makes it hella good.  I'll have to knock one star off since they charge for chips and salsa though...I think that's bullshit!
author: Mike A.

description:
every time i go back up north i hit up this place for the best burritos.  i love how they melt the cheeses, and the burrito gets nice and warm.  they're big and cheap!  i have a big debate with friends about the best Mexican in the city and this one tops my list.

yummy!
author: Alice F.

description: I enjoy eating here because I think their burritos rock. They also have yummy quasediaya (I have no clue how to spell it). The only reason I deducted two stars was becasue it was pretty dirty in there. The floors looked like they haven't been washed in centuries. But I still go there becasue it's one of the most decent Mexican restaurants in the city.
author: Pasta G.

description: Yumminess is Gordo's burritos.  My boyfriend and I love this place!   Best part is that they steam the tortillas, so the cheese gets nice and gooey.  Their fresh salsa verde is great too.
author: Danielle B.

description: Hands down, best burrito around.  I have spent years testing every burrito in the bay area.  This place beats any taqueria in the Mission where all the meat tastes like day-old Chinese food.  I've been to all of their locations and they are all consistent. The only thing that sucks is the "you're annoying me, gringo" attitude that all the employees seem to express.  I'll put up with a little attitude from the "burrito nazis", as I have so affectionately named them, in order to feast on the best.
author: Dan C.

description: Excellent Steak and Chicken Burritos. Excellent guacamole. Would have given them 5 stars, but the guys working their are a little rude. Would it be too much to say hello or acknowledge you when you are ordering. You just get a blank stare.
author: Dave P.

description: This place makes a damn good burrito and quesadilla. They don't overkill their guac with cilantro. Which seems to be the thing in San Francisco. Cheap and in a great location. Dig it!
author: Jonathan R.

description: Good affordable and friendly joint...and if you're into bears, then you'll like the guys working there!  LOL
author: TJ T.

description:
Best burritos in the Sunset. Second best burritos in the city (I think La Cumbre is #1).

I get the super grilled chicken with black beans and a limon jarritos, so you know my bias. MMM.
author: Johann K.

description:
I give it four stars because it serves the Sunset. In the mission, this place would get three stars.

Still, it's not bad.  Go for the carnitas or the boiled chicken. The carne asada is just plain weird, as it comes in hunks of meat unlike nowhere else I've ever been.  The grilled chicken tastes okay, but a close examination reveals it's mainly composed of burnt cancerous portions -- not to mention the fact I've had bones in my grilled chicken before.

They offer all types of beans and tortilla flavors, so that's covered.  They are generous with the servings of everything, making huge burritos.  

Unfortunately, they charge for chips and there's no free salsa. Normally I would automatically deduct a star for this. However they are damn lucky. Why? Because the spicy salsa here is the best pico de gallo in town, Mission district included.  It's spicy, flavorful, and if you pay for it you get a big container big enough to share.  The pico de gallo is the reason I go back.

So don't hesitate to hit up Gordo's, but make sure you shell out the 1.50 for the chips and salsa. The mild salsa isn't just mild, but flavorless, so make sure you get the spicy salsa.
author: Dean A.

description: Can you give less than a star?  These places used to be great, but it seems that an MBA started there and decided to make more money already!  Super burittos were just that, super, now they portion out every item put in the skin.  Sodas got smaller, cups got thinner, straws are like cocktail mixers, what's up?  I've been going here for 10 plus years because it is close by, any place in the Mission can beat this place hands down. What a let down.  Go to Sliders next door.
author: t b.

description: I just go here for the steak burritos.  I started eating here when I was a kid because I met the owner's son through a friend who went to St Cecilia's elementary school.  I still go back to eat here to this day.
author: John D.

description: This is my favorite taco joint.  Haven't been to the others, but this one always fills my belly with good chickeny burritoness.
author: Jackie G.

description:
This neigborhood dangerous. I keep on finding new places to eat!!!!
The burritos are great, the carnitas was so good.I can`t  wait to go back.
author: B O.

description: In my mind, taquerias that keep all their meat in a warmer and don't at least reheat it on a grill or griddle before they serve it to you can only reach a 4-star rating before they plateau. Gordo has reached it for me. Beans are well seasoned, rice is good, and the portions are big! I ordered a carnitas place, which, for just over $5, came in one of those square boxes bursting with rice, beans, meat, and their mild tomato mix. The carnitas taste like the kind I make at home (and for a little asian girl, I make good carnitas), albeit not as hot as I'd like them to be. If you get chips and salsa, don't get the hot salsa unless you really like it hot!
author: Crystal L.

description: I used to eat here quite often and the food is good, but the people behind the counter constantly insult the customers (in spanish). I guess they assume no one speaks spanish in the sunset. After noticing this on a regular basis, I decided not to eat there anymore.
author: J D.

description: Cheap good and fast.  Not much to say but slightly above average.
author: Mike J.

description: So, my friends and I walked to Gordo's to after a game at Kezar a few years back. Not my first choice in burrito joints (cough cough El Burrito Express), but I can hang. I get the same thing I always get (boiled chicken with refried beans, avocado, sour cream, and cheese). As always, it was okay. My only complaint is that the chicken just doesn't have flavor. Anyways if not for the next event, I would have given this place 3 stars. We get our burritos, we sit down, we're talking, I look up and see this: all the guys from behind the counter standing together with their arms folded and leaning back against the wall and just suggestively stared at us as they talked amongst themselves. At this point, we were 17 years old, but that's beside the point. I told my friends and looked back up and they were still staring suggestively. Not okay! That made us feel super awkward and creeped out and we ended up leaving a few minutes after that. AND this happened on two occasions, after being dragged here a second time. Never again!
author: Melissa C.

description: this place has grown on me and i take out of towners looking for a quick fill to cure our crazy nights out.  they've all loved it.  get the chicken burrito with salsa, black beans, guacamole, sour cream, rice and get the HOT SAUCE :-)  it's good.  and it's cheap eats.  soda and burrito for $7.
author: Keri K.

description: i needed a guacamole fix last night, so i walked down here and got a super burrito with chile verde.  it was gross--nothing specifically wrong with it, but it just tasted bland, and i still feel sick thinking about it...
author: Roshni R.

description: This the best burrito in San Francisco.  Loyal customer for 15 years.  For healthy you can go with the boiled chicken which is very tasty.  The carnitas on the opposite end of the spectrum is to die for - Literally!  Also, nowhere makes a quesadilla like Gordo's since you are able to put rice in it.  Try it sometime, it's like a bona fide grilled burrito.
author: nino l.

description: Gordo's is amazing, plain and simple. Never mind that the salsa is made from pink, anemic tomatoes. For about seven bucks, you can get a Gordo plate (contents of the would-be burrito in a take-out box) that serves two. If you're ravenously hungry, nothing beats tasty hot rice, beans, chicken, and guacamole. Gordo's is the only fast food place I know that doesn't serve disgustingly unhealthy food, slippery with grease. Plus, you get to see the workers assemble your burrito!
author: Anita L.

description: Can't lie; this place is part of the reason I moved back to San Francisco.  There's no earthly reason their burritos should be so amazing.  Worth the trip to the Sunset every time.
author: Rebecca H.

description: Good burritos made really fast and I never leave this place without extra guacamole - it's excellent !
author: Alex S.

description:
burrito sucks.
they are made like a chode and are filled with too many beans and not enough meat.
and the store is dirty,
and i might've seen a rat.
also it is overpriced for what you get,
the workers are lame.
screw this place

oh yeah. they charge for chips, how cheap.
i bet their chips suck too. suck penis.
they have no nachos either.
author: W W.

description:
i eat here despite being a texan (we're very snobby about mexican food). 
i've been eating here since they opened this store. i once interviewed the owner about what it took to make a taqueria succeed in a part of the country without easy access to mexican staples and he said it boiled down to the tortillas -- they needed to be made fresh daily, and these certainly are. 
my favorite stuff here is the quesadillas, what wonderfully crispy tortillas. but i also wish that gordo's offered horchata. que lastima!
and the prices are still quite reasonable, folks.
author: Cherry S.

description: Love me some Gordos. I've been going to this place since I was a wee lad, and while it's not the best taqueria in SF (I'd say either El Matate or Taqueria San Francisco take that prize), it is cheap and consistently good. Their carnitas never fails, and I love their guac. The guys are friendly and willing to listen as you try to practice your broken Spanish, which is nice.
author: Daniel K.

description: I've been going to this Gordo's for 24 years and I have serious regular cravings for their boiled chicken and carnitas super burritos, no tomatoes, just green hot sauce, with some sour cream. I get excited like a junkie knowing they are going to get a fix, it's sick. Never too fatty or sloppy or greasy.
author: Marilyn P.

description: pleasantly surprised to discover a gordo's in my new neighbourhood. really surprised when i walked in the door and the guys from their berkeley location greeted me and already knew what i was going to order. sweet!
author: Friedrich G.

description: One of my favorite places to get a burrito. I've been coming here for quite a long time. I even came here when they were two doors down the block which pretty much says how long I've been coming. I always get a super burrito. This may just be me but I can never finish it. Definitely worth a try!
author: Miranda R.

description: the burritos are quite good, but i recommend the rice and bean quesadilla. it is perfect. plus they have unbeatable prices. definitely my favorite mexican food that doesn't come out of a truck.
author: Jessica B.

description:
woohoo as good as it gets!

lol Gordo's is my favorite mexican place and the only thing I eat there is fried carnitas quesadilla.  hedonistic pleasure at its best- grease, salt, meat and spices!
author: alex t.

description: They make really tasty burritos. It is actually pretty easy to make a bad burrito. Just try Carmelina's down the street.  Gordo's burritos make a great burrito...I don't know what it would take to get 5 stars....I'm not sure that burriitos can actually attain 5 stars...so i'll give this place 4 stars with the declaration that they're muy delicioso!
author: Iris M.

description: ah gordo's. well, it's not my favorite burrito place in sf- not by a longshot- but it's not bad. i like the super chicken quesadilla - it's just as tasty as a super burrito, but not anywhere near as gut-busting. (their super's are insanely huge).
author: oona m.

description: ive been underpressed... several times, and they make you pay for chips. Really, why go here when SF has so much amazing mexican to offer like say papalote or la corneta??
author: Genevieve H.

description: Best taco I have ever had! You have to get it crispy and loaded or it will be dry and and bland. Really messy, your going to need chips or a fork for this one. burritos are ok.
author: L A.

description: you'll be done eating for the rest of the day, but a super carnitas with pintos is definitely the way to go. the one out in the richmond is slightly superior, but if i'm craving an amazing burrito i usually can't be bothered to go that far, so this one will do. one question - where are they hiding the health inspection score?
author: lily G.

description: Gordos has the best burrito in the city hands down!!  And the price is unbeatable. Be careful though you can get addicted to this place, I used to eat there three times a week.
author: colin p.

description: Good, big, cheap burritos.  Not amazing across the board, but for the price I cant complaim.  If you find them too bland might want to try La Fonda around the corner, but be prepared to pay another $2 for that extra flavor.  Tip: Ask for pico de gallo, black beans, sour cream, and extra green hot sauce at least.  The guacamole isnt that great, but better than nothing.  If you dont mind dining on swine, the carnitas seems to be my favorite meat option.
author: Jared D.

description: Good food at good prices. Always a solid bet. Especially like the grilled chicken super burrito
author: Bill B.

description: One of the very  best consistent cheap burrito joints around.    Of course, this is wet and fatty.....that's why it tastes so good.   So calorie watchers beware.    Not nice places to sit, but you'll be happy with the food as long as your expectations are right.   Chips are fair, but that's the only real demerit other than the atmo.
author: Barry C.

description: never again, rice tasted disgusting and actually the burrito made me feel nauseous
author: Stuart g.

description: best burrito place in the area.  but i think they charge for sour cream and guocamole.  cheap b**tards!
author: Coconut J.

description: There is nothing remarkable about this place; I could make these myself, but when I'm in San Francisco, they're good enough to grab.  However, they kind of screw you.  In most places "super burrito" means a burrito with cheese, guacamole, and sour cream.  So I ordered the super burrito.  He asked whether I wanted beans (of course) and rice (of course.), then whether I wanted salsa (of course), and also then whether I wanted guacamole and sour cream (asked as though they were a single item).  I said, yes, but only guacamole (liquid in a tube, really), but it was too late; two squirts and I had both.  And then when I got to the cashier the burrito was about two bucks more than the posted price.  It turns out guacamole and sour cream weren't included in the price, and, even though I didn't want the sour cream, I was stuck with it.  I suppose "super burrito" is never defined anywhere in the store, but it's still a bit misleading considering what it means at every taqueria in the Mission.  And I suppose I should have guessed with their low prices, there was some sort of scam going on, but I fell for it anyway.  Buyer beware.
author: M. B.
